node.title: Black Women Make Waves in Hair Care
node.alt: Whitney White, the co-founder and owner of Melanin Haircare at her offices in Hudson, Mass.
node.description: A new crop of businesses are growing their share of a billion-dollar industry.
node.content: ["For more than a decade, Whitney White, a.k.a. @naptural85, has posted hair tutorials on YouTube for Black women, like herself, with natural, coily hair. A self-described natural hair OG, Ms. White, 35, mastered the art of the wash and go (the signature, curl-defining look for \u2018naturalistas\u2019), the pineapple (a way to gather hair at the crown to maintain hairstyles for sleeping) and the twist-out (a twisted, dried, then untwisted hairdo). She also taught viewers how to create nourishing shampoos, deep conditioners and hair masks for optimal hair health and growth.", "Eventually many of her more than two million followers encouraged her to produce her own line of hair products. Now, as the co-founder of Melanin Haircare, she joins the ranks of Black, female-owned companies that sell products that cater to the needs of Black hair.", "\u201cI am a Black woman, so I know what we want,\u201d Ms. White said. \u201cIt\u2019s kind of our FUBU moment.\u201d", "The global hair-care industry, worth an estimated $77.15 billion, is projected to reach $112.97 billion by 2028, according to Fortune Business Insights. Black-owned hair care companies are growing, increasing their market share to $2.5 billion in 2021, according to Mintel, spawning waves of Black, female hair-care enthusiasts with business acumen.", "Recognizing the industry\u2019s considerable size, Monique Rodriguez thought that with her ingenuity she might have success in an industry dominated by people who didn\u2019t look like her.", "\u201cI said, \u2018This beauty industry is over a billion dollars,\u2019\u201d said Ms. Rodriguez, 37, a founder and the chief executive of Mielle Organics. \u201cI should be able to get in here and get a small piece of the pie and serve women that look like me.\u201d", "\u201cI saw there was a lack of relatability and education, and I said, \u2018If I can just serve the underserved, then I can win in this category.\u2019\u201d", "Ms. Rodriguez started Mielle Organics in 2014 while working full-time as a nurse. She, too, turned her passion for developing homemade hair remedies and discussing them on social media into a business.", "\u201cIt\u2019s inspiring, especially for women of color, to see another woman of color pursuing her dreams \u2014 a woman that didn\u2019t have any type of celebrity status, pretty much came from nothing and had a stable career, like the majority of America,\u201d Ms. Rodriguez said.", "Going from nurse to chief executive was not an easy transition for Ms. Rodriguez. She had no guidance and money was tight.", "\u201cI used my nursing paychecks,\u201d she said. \u201cEvery time I got paid, I would dedicate funds to something that had to do with my business. It was a lot of doubt, but I\u2019m really big on manifestation.\u201d", "Like Ms. White, Ms. Rodriguez knew that connecting with women who were seeking guidance on how to style and maintain their textured hair was important and authentic and, consequently, the key to building a brand.", "\u201cNatural hair is not easy,\u201d she said. \u201cEvery curl pattern is different. You have low porosity here. You have high porosity there. Which products do you use according to your hair type? There was no one talking about that.\u201d", "\u201cI felt, \u2018I\u2019m on this natural hair journey, and I want to be educated,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cI want to know how to use the products because every product I used caused my hair to be frizzy. But there was no one to help me understand what I was doing wrong.\u201d", "Ms. Rodriguez, who now maintains healthy, waist-length hair, reckoned that not only could she make great products with high quality ingredients, but she could also help educate customers on how to use the products to get the best results.", "Many Black women have coily, Type 4 hair, which refers to a numeric system created to assess the texture of hair. Because of these compact ringlets, scalp-producing sebum, intended to lubricate hair strands, has a difficult time moving down the shaft, so natural oils are unable to coat and ultimately moisturize the strands. This causes excessive dryness, so moisture needs to be added in the form of co-washes, conditioners, butters, oils and creams. Several Black-owned brands have formulated products that address the specificity of these attributes.", "Oil, specifically Haitian black castor oil, is Kreyol Essence\u2019s signature product. It\u2019s what earned the company an investment deal on \u201cShark Tank\u201d and what allowed it to provide jobs to castor seed farmers in Haiti. Locals have used the seeds for many purposes for generations: to moisturize their hair and bodies, as a healing salve for injuries, and for digestive health. Castor seeds are grown in various parts of the Caribbean, but in Haiti they are traditionally hand-roasted, ground and cooked, producing an unrefined oil.", "\u201cThis is something that is so native from our culture, and it\u2019s part of our everyday life in Haiti,\u201d said Yve-Car Momperousse, 39, the Haitian American co-founder of Kreyol Essence, named after the dominant language of Haiti.", "After embarking on her own natural hair journey, and subsequently having her virgin hair damaged by a beautician, Ms. Momperousse turned to a well-known local Haitian salve, lwil maskriti seeds, rich in various nutrients and fatty acids. She then realized that she could build a business around these ingredients, which would also stimulate the rural Haitian community by connecting with farmers \u2014 many of whom are women \u2014 that were already growing castor plants.", "\u201cThis is something that they made,\u201d Ms. Momperousse said. \u201cIt\u2019s a point of respect for them to see something beautifully packaged. That helps with their self-esteem, too. They ask, \u2018Who is buying all of this, and are they as proud of the end product as we are?\u2019\u201d", "After Kreyol Essence expanded its operations nationally, it made history this past spring as the first Haitian beauty brand on QVC.", "\u201cFor so long, Haiti has had to fight the stigma of being the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere,\u201d she said. \u201cSo, dealing with discrimination, to be able to show a different side of Haiti, to show something that\u2019s beautiful and that people want to receive is a huge deal for us.\u201d", "For Ms. Momperousse, there\u2019s also the added responsibility of speaking for so many people \u2014 as a woman, a West Indian woman, a Black American woman and, most important to her, a Haitian American woman.", "\u201cWe feel like we represent so many different groups, and we don\u2019t want to let them down,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s amazing what happens when you see someone who looks like you, or who has a similar culture or background, and you see them do something. They say, \u2018Keep going, we\u2019re super-proud. You\u2019re representing us.\u2019 That is the highest flattery and the thing that I\u2019m most proud of.\u201d", "Providing an example of strong, female entrepreneurship was equally important to Chris-Tia Donaldson, the founder and chief executive of TGIN: Thank God It\u2019s Natural.", "\u201cYou\u2019re inspiring this next generation of Black women to sustain themselves outside of corporate America,\u201d said Ms. Donaldson, who died from breast cancer in November after being interviewed for this article. \u201cAll of this talent, for the longest time, would go to waste because we would get passed over for promotions. We\u2019d get passed over for leadership and senior management and as the head of corporations. This movement has really given us the opportunity to take back our power.\u201d", "Ms. Donaldson, a Harvard-educated lawyer, developed her brand after writing her first book, \u201cThank God I\u2019m Natural.\u201d Almost 20 years ago, after she stopped relaxing her hair and learned to embrace her kinks and curls, she had an \u201caha\u201d moment.", "\u201cIt was like, \u2018Thank God, I\u2019m natural,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cThank God, I can go swimming, not sit in the hair salon, walk in the rain. I can do all of these things.\u201d", "Ms. Donaldson never set out to be an entrepreneur, she said, but she saw tech start-ups led by young, white men creating innovative products and thought she could do it, too.", "Like Ms. Rodriguez, Ms. Donaldson began the company while working full-time at her day job. To her family, starting a hair-care line lacked the prestige of being a corporate lawyer, but she pressed on, frustrated by the lack of industry support at the time.", "\u201cYou\u2019re scared because you\u2019re growing this company, and you have no blueprint for it,\u201d she said. \u201cThere was Carol\u2019s Daughter, there was Miss Jessie\u2019s, but you always feel like, \u2018How do I grow that big?\u2019\u201d", "Today, wearing natural Black hair is a statement of pride, a repudiation of an imposed beauty standard and a determined declaration of Black identity. Further emboldened by the passage of the Crown Act in 2019, which banned discrimination based on hair style and texture and has now been adopted by 14 states, Black women now have the cultural, and legal, right to wear their hair in a manner of their choosing.", "For a long time, many people in African American communities believed that mainstream hair care companies lacked quality customer service and took their Black customers for granted. As a result, Black-owned companies are held to a higher standard by their consumers, who expect a certain level of authenticity and efficacy.", "\u201cWe\u2019re just so used to companies not really caring about us,\u201d Ms. White said. \u201cThey think we\u2019ll accept anything. People know we will spend a lot of money on our beauty care. With Melanin Haircare, we wanted to give the community a quality brand that didn\u2019t pander, that knows what they need and serves it to them at an affordable price.\u201d", "Because many Black-owned hair care companies started with a mission to help Black women, philanthropy is often a part of their mission. After the devastating earthquake in Haiti, Kreyol Essence donated funds to two hospitals in the affected area and used a QVC broadcast to raise awareness to the network\u2019s audience.", "Mielle\u2019s More Than a Strand initiative helps female entrepreneurs with funding and resources to get their ventures off the ground. Through its Global Certificate Program, as part of its partnership with Rutgers University and the Newark Business Hub, the company recently allocated 60 grants to aspiring female business owners.", "Mielle\u2019s global ambassadors, the actress Keshia Knight Pulliam and the rapper Megan Thee Stallion, help push the company\u2019s agenda of business education. This commitment to philanthropy helped to attract Berkshire Partners to invest in the company.", "Part of the learning curve of Black female entrepreneurship is leading by example, showing that women can succeed in traditionally male-dominated spaces. In Haiti, Ms. Momperousse often travels to rural areas to negotiate with male farmers, who, uncomfortable with her leadership, initially speak directly to her male colleagues instead of to her, she said.", "They attempt to disparage her authority by telling her, \u201cYou look like my daughter.\u201d To which she responds: \u201cTell your daughter she can do it, too.\u201d"]
